conclusion: Understand the relationship between velocity of two objects moving in the same direction and how their separation changes over time.
Identify the objects and their initial positions. Object A starts at velocity v0 at t1, and Object B starts at velocity v0 at t2.
Determine the separation distance between the two objects at any given time t. Separation distance d(t) is given by the absolute difference in their positions: d(t) = |xB(t) - xA(t)|.
Analyze the velocity-time graph to find when the separation distance is maximized. Maximum separation occurs when the two objects are moving in opposite directions.
From the graph, identify the time t3 when the two objects are farthest apart. This is when the velocity of Object A is equal to the velocity of Object B.
Verify that at t3, the separation distance d(t) is maximized.
Conclude that the two objects are farthest apart at t3.
The problem involves analyzing the motion of two objects moving in the same direction, using their velocity-time graph to determine when they are farthest apart.
The separation distance is calculated as the absolute difference in their positions at any given time.
The maximum separation occurs when the objects are moving in opposite directions, which is when their velocities are equal.
At t3, the two objects are farthest apart.
